div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: THE FATE OF THE DUMA.
div.p: Seldom, if ever, in the annals of a great Empire in times of peso has such a snccession of important events lean reported as*waa fent by Renter, and published by ni» ou Monday,, concerning Russia. Bach item is pregnant with most momentous possibilities, and taken to¬gether they present a terrible pictore of the state of Russia at the present time. An Imperial Ukase has dissolved the Dama, the building in in which it met being closed and guarded by

We purposely refrain from commenting on 'the growing disaffection of both army and \navy and the symptoms 6f revolt that are plainly to be seen in both servioes, as we are at present concerned with the suppression of the Dama—the representative bxly established only a short while back by the Tsar in the of satisfying the political aspirations of his people. From the very fir«t, in spitA of a restricted franchise and every possible obstacle that coaid be devised Ur'obstraot its action, the Duma has proved itself a thorn in the side of the Tsar aud his Government. Its re¬cent manifesto in favour of the naturalisation of the land and the expropriation of landlords has ptJved the last >traw, and we read that the deoiaion to d:ssolve the Dama was oome to at a meeting of the Conqpil of the Empire at which, as might be expected, Grand Dakes, Coart efti nals, General Trepoff, etc., weie pre- v sent. To os it v^onId almost appear as if the Dama had oonrted disaster by a premature ooarse of aotion. Land nationalisation is still a dream of the fatare even in a country like England with its free institution*. To propose it in a oonntry not yet emerged from auto¬cratic government looks very much like at¬tempting to ran before yoU oan walk. The members of the l7omsr however, have proved themselves by no moans deficient in ability, and possessing as they do full knowledge of the sufferings and wants of the agrionltorid Jom- monity and the argent necessity of drattib measures of reform, they most have decided that they were folly jastifiod in issuing so decisive a challenge to the Government "The King is dead, long live the King.” Everybody understands'?tbe meaning of this phraie, which is so generally used as to have become almost a proverb; when, however, the phrase is applied in another direction it may have a different significance. At the meeting of members of .the Parliaments of Europe and America which took plaoe jn London onMondiy last, and, which was attended by Several members of the Dama, Sir Henry Campbell- Badnerman expressed the King and Govern- msnts' ‘sympathies with the objects of the oonfsrence and, allndicg to suppreasion of the Dnma, exolaimed “The pama is dead, long live the Duma” The Home Press seem to agree in describing the exp/eesion as a “daring” one, the Conseivative organs cen¬suring and the Liberal papers praising it. Seeing however, that the Tsar hassconvoked a new assembly for the 5th ofrifcxt March, and that the European Press ubauimonsly ojudemn the dissolution of the late one, we do not tbitk the Prim? Minister’s expression ill-jadged.

'The fate of the Dams shows ns that, at any rate for the present, the attempt to introduce Constitutional Government in Russia has fail-ed and farther, that the reactionary party is still strong enough to compel the Tsar to do its will. Itusria seema to be going from bad to aorse.; At the olose of the late war some hope Jelt that the worst had passed and thiti brighter era was about to dawn. But t j-day the sky is darker than ever, and no oce can tell when, or in what direotioD, the storm will burst. As far as oan be seen there is not one singleoapableleaderof the poople,and where in the event of a revolution the guiding hand woald come from, that etloce coaid restrain the passions of the populace, none can foretell. Kassia to-day is the"YjouDtry of anarchy, honeycombed more than ever with secret societies who oarry on almost with impunity au organised system of mniderj and it is snpb a moment that the Tsar Jias cho an Yor the suppression of.a body of pablio men aoting openly and oouragojnsly in'the face of the reactionaries to whom he seems to have surren- lered himself, body. We may admire his courage and devotion to duty in staying at home to face the mosio instead of paying visits abroad ; but oannot shat oar eyes to the fact that time as it passes reveals more and more his 'incapacity to rule and his niter inoompetence to cope with the great origin that is evidently fast.

PAN-AMERICAN CONGRESS.
Rio DK JANEIRO, July 24.
The l’an-AmerioanU^ngresa opened yester¬day.. AU of South ^America isv represented except Venezuela. t (Feuter)

Mr. Van Polk, a grandnephew of President Polk, and ex Consul General at Caloutta,who is one of the United States delegates to the 1 Pan-American Congress at Rio de Janeiro, h is made an interesting statement on the pro¬gramme ot that asaomb'y to a representative of the "Gaulois.” He began by stating • hat the ooDgress will not involve a menace to Europe o^anextension of the Monroe doctrine. It is simply an attempt at a rapprochement between the African Republics, with the object of bringing a^bont an understanding on their oommeroial and Customs"relations, andj endeavouring to constitute a tribunal for ar¬bitration between the American S atev. Tne Hague Tribunal is too far off and, moreover, they wish to manage their own affairs. Neither Canada nor the other British, French ai d Dutch colonies, nor Venezuela are takxg part in this oongreas, at which the United Staten will b$ve six representatives —two diplomatists, an ex Governor, and three professors of law and history. Furthermore, in-order to em phaaize the union of the two Americas, Mr Root, the Secretary of State, has undertaken a voyage round the oontiuentin an American man- of-war, which was to arrivb-at Rio de Janeiro for the opening of the oingress. On its return voyage Mr. Root will tieit other capitals, such as Montevideo, Buenp4 AyreasSantiago, Lima.

The Argentine representative intea’a to submit a motion to the cougreis denying to the European as well as to Ameriosn States the right of intervention in any American State or even the right of seiz:ng the Customs for the recovery of private debts. ^The repre sentative of the "Gaulois” objected that a State loan raised in France or in England was not a privatejdebt. Mr. Van Polk insisted that is was, adding:—'.It is private persons who have subscribed it Sc much the worse for them it they have allowed themselves to be deoeived by intermediaries, or if, knowing the conditions of the loan, they aooepted the usurious rates of interest wbioh olearly io- dioated the risks' they ran. There have been veritable scandals in this respect. If there are Republics which are badly governed we cannot' for that reason agree to see them ruined in order to enforce the payment of money which they haye not receive I in full.”

Mr. B-yn urged that such investigation would elucidate facts and that it was a hun- lre 1 to quo i hit the settlemeyfof facts wonld us-ult in (ho settlement of questions of national honour and would give time for the mobilisa¬tion of the public conscience. THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE IN EGYPT. *
One bund cd and thirty seven gentlemen received per in io don to practise their pro fessiou in. Egypt during 1905.

Any pe/sou in possession of a diploma from a recognised school of medicine is allowed to practise bis profession in Egypt after having presented his diploma at the offices of the Fablio Health Department for verification and paid a small fee of six piastres.

The inflax of mftdioal men into Egypt of late years has beeu very great, and it is diffi¬cult to understand how many of them are able to gain a livelihood from their profession. The effective control of diplomas which ema¬nate from eo many different foreign sohoola is at times somewhatdifficnlt, as tbeaathoritieshave uo means of identifying theperson who presents the diploma as the person who underwent the examinations which entitled him to it; e.g., there is nothing to prevent a person who has oome into possession of a diploma by frandn- leut means personifying the legitimate owner of the diploma and obtaining a lioenoefco praotiee. It is trne that in Addition t/the diploma a certificate of good pondupt is ne¬cessary from the applicant's Consol before a licenoe to praotise is granted, but in many oases the Consol finds himself in the same difficulty as the F.H.D. with regard to ascertain¬ing if the pertou in possession of the cUplomo is the rightful owner or not. This very oloarly proved in the case of some chemists who endeavoured to obtain a licence to praoti^ Jaring 1905 on the presentation of forged dip lorn as, wbioh were so well exeouted that (hoy deceived the Consol fiimself.

div.head: PHARMACIES IN EGYPT. EFFECT OF THE RECENT LAW.
div.p: The law for the control of pharmacies and sellers of poisons has now been in force for a period of over a year, and though at first it met with a considerable amount of opposition on the part of the profession in general, which was due to the faot that the provisions of the law were not thoroughly understood, it was soon disoovered, after the law was pat in toroe, that it pressed hardly on’y on those pharmacies Which were conducted in an irregular manner, the suppression of which were as much in the interests of the respectable chemists as in that of the general public.

There are at present 258 licensed chemists in Ejypt, and we learn from the Pablio Health Department report, just issued, that daring the past year 285 inspections of the»e shops were made, 116 of which *^were carried, ont in Cairo. The resalt of these inspections has beon that 4Oxohemists* shops have been dosed, some by ordbr of the Coarts, and others By the proprietors themselves to obviate further against them.

e inspectors in oarrying ont,their work have met with no opposition on the part of the proprietors, and the Chief Iospeotor acknowledges the ooarteons manner in which he and* his assistants have been received, and the general desire on the part of the respect¬able members of the profession to oomply in every respect with the law.

The law of 1904 forbids unqualified dispen sera to be in oharge of ohemists’ shops ;-tbat these unqualified men are being replaced by fnlly qualified ohemists is proved from the faot that during 1995, 75% more ohemists have been authorised to practise their profession in •Egypt than were authorised} daring 1904.
Foraod Diplomat * ^

Very great oare has to be ekeroised in grant ing authorisations to practise to persons pre¬senting* ohemists* diplomas from foreign schools, as daring the last year three diplomas were found to be forged, and another applicant was toned to be in possession of a diploma of a person who bad been dead for a con¬siderable number of years ; in all cases where there is cause for suspicion the applioaDt is questioned on matters relating to .bis profes¬sion before he is allowed to praotise.

The Chief Inspector reports that since the new law has been in foroe there has been a marked and general improvement in the ohe mists' shops throughout the coaptry, that chemists'shops without qualified chemist* in charge of them are almost unknown, and that the parity and freshness ot drugs in the shops have much improved. The substitution of cheap imitations for new and expensive drugs was discovered in 16 instanoss and legal pro¬ceedings were taken in eaoh case.

A manual of instructions has been issued by the Department as a guide to ohemists as to the best manner in which to arrange their shops and though unofficial, and offered only as a recommendation, it has ■ been aooepted /knd very largely followed.
Sale of Poleont.
The portions of the, law relating to the con¬trol cf the sale of poisons in the country has not met with the same amount of sneoess.

Under the old decree there were 427 licen¬sed poison sellers throughout the oountry j on the promu’gation of the new decree the old licences became null and void*, and persons desiring to sell poisons in the oonntry bad to apply for a new licence wbioh could ouly be granted under much more stringent conditions; only 40 new licences ha've been issued under the new law, so that it is reasonable to suppose that tbejllicit sale of poisons is taking place on a large scale.

In the opinion of the Chief {nspeotor the reasons why so few persons apply for the licence are the somewhat onerous conditions imposed on a trade which does not bring large returns, the applicant being obliged to be a person of respectability,able to read and write,and possess ing a knowledge of the poison, etc., be desires to sell, and competeut to keep bis registers in a regular manner and the obligation to provide a special room -in which to keep the poisons. With regard to the detection of persons carry¬ing on the illicit sale of poisons, Art. 27 of the decree gives the . right to’inspeot drug-shops where the illioit sale of poisons is suspected, but as the sale of poisons usually takes place in shops which are not drag shops, and often in privite booses, this right is of little practical value. The right of search under the Penal Code cannot be exercised as the offence is only a contravention.
U»o of Opium.

It is not morally known, I imagine (says Sir H. Piuohing),. how very general the use o. opium is among the native population, and as the poppy is cultivated to a very large extent, especially in part* of Upper Egypt, the control of the sale of this drag under present condi¬tions is almost impossible. One may often see on mark it days the natiyi opium being hawfielabont the streets by the fellaheen who bring it in from their fields. It is therefore a question . whether a properly authorised and controlled opiam trade woqld not be preferable to the trade as at present carried orvand which is virtually uncqatrollable. The growth of the poppy will have to be strictly controlled io the conntry if the Government desires to Jimit the trade in this poison.
By the law of 1901 the'sale of opium is forbidden except by chemists on the prescrip¬tion of a member of the medioal profession,

div.head: EGYPT AND SINAI. RESPECTIVE POSITIONS DEFINED.
div.p: The following, extract from a despatch of Lord Cromer, contained in the White Paper reoently issued, is ,of retrospective interest .—

In order to understand the somewhat oom- plioated question which has reoently arisen in connection with the frontier of the 8inai Peninsula, some knowledge of the'previous history of the claim of Bgypt to. administer the peninsala is neoessary.
It cannot be doubted that Bgypt has.^M a matter of faot, been in possession of this* territory for many oeotnriee.
A well-known Arab geographer and historian, who liked and wrote between 1274 and 1332 (El Malik Aba-el-Fida by name), described the .easttrn frontier of Egypt as follows:— .

"Egypt is bounded on the east from a point on th? Bahr el Kalzam [Red Sea] opposite Assouan to Izib Kosseir Kalztm [present 8uez], to the wandering desert of the Israelites, and thenoe turns northwards to the Mediterranean at Rafeh of 61 AtisL"

The position of Egypt in more modern times is based mainly on the Firmans of J841, con- firming Mehemet Ali and. his heirs in the possession of the Pashalik. A map showing the boundaries of the territories which were to be henceforth regarded as Egyptian was drawn np in duplicate in 1841. One oopy was retaine 1 by the Porte and oue oopy was given to Mehemet Ali. This map is supposed to have been lost in a fire whrch destroyed a great part of the Egyptian archives. The Turkish oopy is occasionally alluded to by the Porte in oorroepondenoe, but, as far as I know, no one has ever seen it, and its exist- ence appears doubtfal The Turkish Govern- ment olaims that, aooordiug to this map, the eastern frontier of "the privileged Provinoe of Egypt” runs from El Arisfi tozSaez. la addition, however, to the territory defined in this map (and guaranteed by the Powers). Mehemet Ali was empowered to administer the Sinai Peninsala and to hold the posts of Akiba, Dibbah (not the same as Taha), Maelh, W^jh, in the Hedjaz, on the eastern ahorexof the Go’f of Akkba. In this oonneotion it any bs objerved that, As already stated, the Sinai Penimula had been administered by Egypt from of old ; and, farther, that, as regards the poets in the Hedjiz, Mehemet Ali was already in possession*of them, having saved Arabia for the Saltan by the suppression of the Wahabi rebellion raised by Saond. The suppression of this rebellion was oompleted by Ibrahim Pasha, eldest ion of Mehemet Alifin 1818. The grant of the admi- nistration of Sinai was therefore merely a formal recognition of the existing state of things.
The successors of Mehemet Ali continued to admindter this territory without question until the accession of the present Khedive. Of this there is abundant proof in the Egyptian arohives.

On the death of Tewfik Pasha and the acces- sion of his son, Abbas Hilmi Pasha.(the present Khedive), a fresh Firman of Investitare was issued by the Saltan. It was notioed that the text of this Firman differed from that of for- met Firmans. The object ot this differenoe was apparently to exolnde Egypt from the adminis- tration of the Sinai Peoinsnla.

After considerable difficulty and correspond- ence the then Grand Vizier, Jevad Pasha, addressed a telegram to the Khedive, dated the 8th April, 1892, aooording to which the Saltan resumed possession of the posts garri- soned by. Egypt on the Hedja (or eastern) ooast of the Golf of Akaba, via,, of El Wijh, Moelh. Dibbah (not to be confused with Taba), and Akaba. The telegram ended this:—

"As regards the Tor Sinai Peninsula, the statue g_uo is maintained, and it will be ad- ministered by the Khedivate in the sa^e manner as it was administered in the time of your grandfather, Ismail Pasha, and of yonr father, Mehemet Tewfik Pasha."

As the above-named posts in the Hedjaz, reclaimed by Turkey were of no importance to Egypt, this telegram was considered satis- factory, and was publicly read with the Firman of Investiture, of which it has always been considered to form a complementary part.

However, in order to avoid any possible misoederdandirg as to tue meaning of this telegram, I addressed a note, dated thesJ3th April, 1892, to Tigrane Pasha, at thaSims Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, stating that, a9 his Exoellenoy was aware, no alte- ration could be made in the relatione between the Snblime Porte and Egypt without the oomentof Her Majesty’s Government. I added—

The telegram from the Grand Vizier, whioh your Excellency has done me the honour to communicate to me, makes it dear, however, that the Sinai Peninsala—that is to say, the tenitory boanded to the east by a line running in a south-easterly direction trom a point a short distanoe to the east of El Ariah to the i head of the Golf of Akaba—ito oontinne to be administered by Egypt. The fort oi Akaba, I which lies to the east of the line in question, , will thus form part of the Vilayet of. the Hedjaz.” I

This note, which was sobrequeutly approved by L)rd Salisbury, was publi«hea, with other correspondence respecting the Firman of Inves- , titure, and oopiesof the latter and of the Grand Vizier’s supplementary telegram, were offioial'y communicated to Her Majesty’s Ambassador at Constantinople. I
This point is of importance, as the elaim ot His Majesty's Government to be entitled to objeot to any alteration of the situation thns created is thereby fully justifhd.
Copies of the Firman of Investiture and of the annexed telegram wfcre alio oommonioeUd to other Powi, and the Repreeentativee offrance and Russia in Cairo officially act” of the communication.

from what I have stated it will be aeea th'.t the toe them ecd of the eastern frontier of the territory administered by Bgypt was Akaba, bat exdaded the fort at that place, itafeh, at some distanoe east of El Arish. ha« always been reoognizri as ths point from whioh this frontier begins on th) north.
At Rafeh there is a tree, and oa eaoh side of this tree there has been for many years a marble pillar, m»rkiug the "Egyptian and Turkish boundary.

div.head: NEW ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: On Monday night I Granatieri was given by the Lombardo operetta oompany at .the New Abbas Theatre. As a mnsioal oomedy the play is very poor, the plot being quite good, bat the masio ragged and unattraotive—at least, so it seemed on.this oooasion. The part 6f Mimi was played very unsatisfac¬torily by Signora Giaseppina Calligaris, who |bias got a harsh and uuplearing voioe and seemed to imagine that an immutable grin, ample gesticulation, and -heavy lurches aoross the stage were sufficient to create the rdle. Signora Montis played the part of Dorotea frirly well though somewhat stiffly, but the insignificant part of Beatrice was very well given by Siguora G. Lombardo. Urbano it always good and invariably amuses his au- dience, and as Bernardo he proved no ex- oaption. The role of 11 Marchese di Large- trou was well enttasted to 8»g. Piraooini, and both 8ignori Cnrti and 8aoohi represented Odoardo and G orgio satisfactorily, though without particular esprit. On the whole the play was poorly represented and fell flat before a very small audienoe.

div.head: PUNCH IN JUDEA
div.p: London, after all, to the bewilderment of Englishmen, is a cosmopolitan city,

particu-larly in the matter of its drama. The American drama is an established institution in the metropolis, the Gibson Girl one of the signs of the timet The French and UermaD theatres are hardy Anunals ; the Yiddish theatre, like the race which it seeks to please, and which to some extent it typifies, a restless wanderer.

So often, however, does the Yiddish thea tre find à temporary resting plaoe in the East End/ that its friends have been anxious to see it1 settled there permanently.. Yiddish- loving playgoers have long cast envioQs eyes on New York, which has its Yiddish as well as its Chinese theatre open all • the year roand. A few years back, the Yiddish theatre was planked down on a so called permanent* basis, in the Manor Hall, Hackney, but it dia not find itself comfortable there. Moreover/ it was not the beat centre, and the ventnie was short lived. Still, the The’pian wanderer found a home at fairly regnlar intervale, at various halls and theatres in the East End, and was always rapturously welcour- ed by the elder sons and'daughters of Judea.

Then, a year or so ago, a board went np on a vacant space in Commercial read, blsz. ming forth the faht that here was to ri-e the Orient, a temple of Thespis, with Eastern cupolas above and boards for the permanent rest ug- plaoe of the wanderer beneath. Complete plans and illustrations of* the bnildirg appeared in one or two papers—and then silence. But in anEglish theatre noir at haod the Yiddish drama looks like sett’iog down.

For the present, the Pavilion Theatre, Mile End, jnst on th^feorder line otthe Whitechapel and Mile End Constituencies, is crowded at every performance. O-oe night the fare is his¬torical or sacred drama, the next^modern farce, for the Jewish dramatic literature is all em¬bracing and extensive. x And practically every piece is half operatic. All^Yiddish plays are musical. To the denizens of the Ghetto music is one of the compensations of life,and a Yiddish play without tuneful vocal numbers would be like a wedding withoutjhe bridegroom.

An amazing literature is the 'Yiddish drama, it embraoee all perils and qvery conceivable kind of play, and probab’y the most popular are the oomedies. Home of them are farcical to the verge of burlecqae. many are daringly satirical, and there are few oomio song) in the English language that can equal the best of the Yiddish humorous ditties for subtlety. English music hall songs have gained considerably in point by translation. Yiddish, in a sense, is a polyglot language. Wherever it lacks a word; it bonows from the language nearest at hand. Under the oiroomstances, it is amazingly mobile, and its elasticity makes it a unique medium for the conveyance of humorous sug-gestion and the portrayal of caricataje.

And just as Yiddish is the language of humour, so are Jewish sentiment and tradition the vehiolee ofmelody. Quaintly plaintive are the melodies for the most part, breathing the hope, the yearning, and the deathless spirit of the Jew, and no matter how the theatre has echoed to the shoots of uproarious laughter, a silence that is almost eerie will fall on the andienoe at tho soond of the music that finds a quick response in the hearts whose inner¬most secrets it voices so well. Jewish mosic is even more distinctive than is Jewish drama, for it is purely native. The drama has not hesitated to borrow, ahd there are quaint translations and adaptations^ Shakspeare, Ibsen, and modern melodramatic, writers have all been bononred in this way, and Mr. Sey¬mour Hicks coaid not better display the in- genoity which is shown by Jewish an’lnrs in the introduction of songs.

With a repertoire eo vast and varied, and for the most part a change of programme nightly, the. ta*k of the Yiddish actor is no light one. But although the Jews have given of their best to the dramatic talent of more than one Continent, the/ still retain sufficient to make the histrionic versatility of the Yiddish theatre its most wonderful character istic. Practically every actor and actress in the Yiddish theatre is a vocalist as well as a mere mime, and the combination which is so rare elsewhere is here quite ordinary.

But with the plethora of p'ays presented, the sadden deviations from the programme and the inevitable changes in cast, the promp-ter is the personage of the greatest impor¬tance in the Yiddish playlnnse JLt the Pavilion the conditions are those of an ap-to date and modern theatre bat at the small halli in London and the. provincesApre’sed into temporary service, the arrangements have resulted in queer onrthcarstd ifl’epts. Buj a Yiddish audience is indulgent, except to a .villain like Esterhazy, whose representative in a Dreyfus play was mobbed, and generally accepts the situations as additional opportn nities f>r laughter. And not infrequently the actors who are favourite« take advantage of this good nature, with the full permission of the audience.

This strange (tonne camaraderie between aadiencp and actor gave rise to a most ludi- croas scene daring the performance of aSiberian play. The usual crowd of miserable looking exiles were being driven across tho snowbound steppes. An old man fell out of the ranks and begged piteously for water. The crael soldiers replied with threats, curses, tbs lash. The hero prote-tedf in vain. The comic rpan made asides, to relieve the tension. But the audiet ce were in hissing not in laughing moodt and the come¬dian grew desperate. His reputation was at stake. Hastily he jumped to the frqntof the stage, and, seizing'dne ofthe' ffre Fqqkets there, he rushed to the fallen .prisoner' and cried gxaltantly, 'Drink !” With a wry face the poor
SOURCE OF BLUE NILE.’ —
AN INTERESTING NARRATIVE?

A journey into the far interior of the African Continent is no longer synonymous with a plunge into a mysterious unknown world. Virgin soil the traveller may no doobt still find in the interstices of the ^network of tra¬vellers* routes which cover the continent, but the meshes of the net are grown comparative’y small and the work of sub division is constantly in progress. If the pioneer explorer entered into possession of Africa in the Nineteenth Century, the sarveyor may ba sail to have inherited thft continent in the Twentieth Cen¬tury. This change in the eharaoter of African exploration is oue of the chief impressions left by a perusal of the volume in which, under the title “The‘Source of the Blae Nile,”. Mr. A. J Hayes has given an acconnt of a journey through the Sadan to L‘ki Tsana, in Western Abyssinia. European oivilisati m has not yet fastened its grip on Western Abyssinia, but various explorers h id viaited Lake Tsana before Mr. Hayes and his companions, and throughout the narrative the e is a feeling that the travellers were never vary far out of touch with the outside world. K/eu on the shores of the lake Mr. Hayes received by Abyssinian post a letter that had been despatched from Port Slid on the day on which he left Cairo. Tfo impression of the change brought in the condit:oos of African travel is perhips height ened in the present instance by the otli )ial character of the enterprise, the expedition a sarvey ronnd the shores of Lake Tsana, and, in particular, to secure observations at the place where the Abai, or Bloe Nile, issues from the lake.

Mr. Hayes has strong together the incident* occapies the remaining third, is scarcely more than a collection of extracts. It is, perhapv^ little disconcerting to find iu a narrative/ of travel that the traveller is constantly oontent to convey his impressions and information by second hand. But whatever may be thought of the method adopted by Mr. Hayes—and it has .at least the merit of honesty—he has brought ' together a great deal qf carious information, and the more unpirdonab’e therefore is the omission from the volume of .an index in any shape qr fortn. Two maps are supplied. ohe of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan aid the other of Lake Tsana, and a number of illustrations re¬produced from photographs add interest to the narrative
The Soufec of tho Blue Nile. By Arthur J. Hayes, L.S. A. Illustrations ami M;\ps. Smith, Elder. ai|d Co. 10s. lid. nut. i

The Egyptian State Railways have the ho-nour to inform the public that, to avoid overcrowding .of the Railway goods-platforms dariog the Cotton season, and the confusion necessarily resulting therefrom, the following egulations will be enforced:—
’“1—All consignments must be separated from one another by a minimum distance of two feet.
“2-Consignments must be well arranged and stacked together.

“3—When one lot of consignments has been received and staoked on one platform no more-will be allowod t) be plaoed on that platform until there is vaoant space, t.e., all stacking of subsequent consignments on the top of these already existing will be prohibited. '
“4—Aunffioient spaoe most be left on each platform as a roadway for oarts.

“Should theJ find that these ar-rangements are not being carried out, and that there is. oonfasion amongst the consign-ments, notice is hereby given that in each a case the gates of the station will be (hat,* and no more consignments will be aooepted until the platforms are empty, and there¬after receipt will only be given for tho amount of goods for* which wagons are avail able each day.

“The Railways invite the co-operation of the public in oarrying out these regulations, oyhich will avert , the irregularities ^and oon¬fasion whioljxarosa at several stations'during the last Cotton Season.

div.head: ThE-TURKISH NOVEL. A THING OF SHREDS AND PATCHES AND OF POPULARITY.
div.p: The Turk has an insatiable appetite for bright brief talcs of love and adventure, ,the roraautio and the supernatural ; and it may be justly said that, with certain limitations, the short story has been brought to perfection in Turkish literature.
The limitations—by which I mean the exist¬ing and apparently unalterable conditions that prevent Tojkish fictional literature from tak ing a 'place of unqualified excellence—are threefold. , •

Firstly, ^aJx^ori gio. The Turk haiever been an eft’uient and offen enthusiastic imitator, but not a creator. He adapts from the Arabio, the Persian, even from claftic Indian literature; or, on the other side geographically, from the Hungarian, "the German-Austriar, the French, altering names, characters and locality to fit his case. Of forty stories which came to my notice during a recent Balkan journey, rt least thirty were adaptations.

Secondly, as to veraoity. The ludicrous one sidedness of the Turk is well koowp to travellers and stadewta. It oaused Mfltke to exclaim, several decades ago, “The Turks write ii Hated bombast and call it history.” An absurd partiality for anything Turkish, or at least Mps'em,.aud a grotesque aversion to *aff?thicg E iropeanand Christian —hat, strange to say, not to Jdws or things Jewish - lis- figure even the most poetical and brilliant productions ofTurkish fictional literature.

Thirdly, as to thd mode of distribution. This is twofold and, under both forma, so utterly un-Buropean that it requires an effort of imagination on the part of the Ocoidental who does not know Tarkey to grasp Che conditions which obtain on the business-side of Ottoman literature.

The first distributing medium is the manuscript, which takes the place ofour circulating library, and is the acknowledged means of oironlaticn. for longer storied, say those of more than ten thousand words. Pro- tlwioial soribes copy the prodactions of literary men, and often copy them* beautifully, with scroll-work, illuminated borders and head¬ings, and the artistlo monogtam work invented by the Arabs a faH thousand years ago. Theae copies oircnlate principally among the ladies and ate passed on from harem to harem. The copyist is also the bookseller or librarian ; the author generally remains in the background, and often his name is not even mentioned.

This is the reason why, with few exceptions, there are no famons names in Turkish fiction, no Dickecs, no Thackeray. It is also the reason of the often heard diotum of superficial observers that Tarkey has no literature.

She has a vast literature, and a not incon¬siderable portion of it is of splendid quality ; but most of it is anonymous. The author receives bis remuneration from the eoribe, who, in most cases, simply buys the original manuscript for a fixed sum and makes three or four oopies of it. There are, however, some few authors, men of high class families, of wide acquaintanceship, and of political and ctfioial influence, who can afford to do without the middleman. They ate either their own scribes, if they are sufficiently good penmen, exactly as the great composer Bach was his own copperplate engraver, or they employ salaried copyists, and theD do their own distributing, among families and households ..whore they have power and social standing. 'These authors often sell their copies, instead of merely lending them.

The second distributing medium is the pro-fessional storyteller. He is the middleman for the short story, say anything between five hundred and ten thousand words. From time immemorial the majori*y of the professional reoitersfef Turkey have been 3yrians„who can declaim at will in Turkish, in Arabic, in Syrian . (sio ?). Only those who have heard the reciter iu his perfection in some .obsouTe, out-of-the- way cife, never mentioned by oar Baedekers ynd od$ MurrayJ, never dreamt, of by Cook’s couriers and Stangeu’s guides, can have an idea of his consummate skill, of bis power and passion, of the wonderful, modulations of his voice, of the poetry of his whole being, which shows even in the expression on bis keen, furrowed, bearded face.
Up to ten or fifteen years ago the remunera¬tion of the professional reciter came exclusively from the audience, in the shape of collections made during the evening and far into the night.

But these Ool’.ections have fallen into discredit, since they, are a disagreeable reminder of the cafe chantant in which the female singers and dancers hand the plate round after each number. Thus, many reciters are now paid a salary'by the cafe proprietor, and some of them command high wages, since their art attracts {tin customers more effectively than, miro fnaV^ooff-e or tea or lemonade. But whether be be salaried or dependent on the guests’ bounty, it is to the reciter’s interest to keep Irmself well supplied with striking novel^ ties. He is thns the beB\ indeed practical# the only client and patron of'the authored ( à it J, short. storieA, whosoprodoce he buys in nxHtj — x cases outright with -the manuscript. Here, I again, the author is hardly ever mentioned. I: have listened to nearly a hundred short tales J read by public reciters from manuscripts, and in only one instance can I recall the name of , the author being given,-and that appeared to ' be solely because the writer was also a states¬man well known to the. a« dience, though not to nfo.

The Turk is notoriously ^tr ci torn and secretive, the Syrian donbly sb, and it is extremely difficult to obtain reliable data as to an author’s remuneration. But in one case, at least, I succeeded in penetratiug the secret of the trade, and that was the case of ‘ a novelof forty thousand words written by an author egyptians and the recent having sufficient influence and connection to egyptians and t HE re cent do without a middleman. He himself made three clean copies of the work, two. of which he sold to friends, high dignitaries of State, for £T. 40 each -the Turkish pound is- equal to 18 sterling. The third copy he lent to various households for perusal, and iu that manner got about £T. 10 from it. The original M3, be finally sold to a m.ddleman for further reproduction, so getffng'-another £T. 10. This novel, with the copies, constituted a year’s work, and the financial result of that years labour was thus £T. 100. It n^ual be remem- beied that the Tark n habitually lazy thia particular man was more than usually idle ; he could easily have doubled, even trebled, bis produce during the twelve months, and he had sufficient power and notoriety to dispose of all that he Wrote.

Knowledgeot the amount pud for a story in Qne other case camo to my notice ;but the details given to me were, not indisputable. I heard the story from the lips of a reciter rho professed to have given £’!’. 16 for the mana script.. He was interested in magnifying his bargain ; let us, therefore, presume that £T. 10 was nearer the mark, and that would meau £9 .ofyOufamouey for a tale of sixz thousand words.

That particular story, with the alterations necessary to make it palatable to English ears, I have reproduced in my recent book, ‘Bypaths in the Balkans under the Watchtower. I may add, at tin risk of appearing egoti loal, that once i had the extraordinary experience of having to listen to , ,Now- why did they behave such ,de a turkish translation sadly disfigured. of oneb>e mannert ‘the english whohave of my own English productions. No author was mentioned, and I remained incognito.

Those who do not know the turks personally are apt to think are apt to think that the ordinary Osmanli’s praotioal ignorance of sexual love and court¬ship must be a grave di qualification in regard to fiction, because in the Oco:dent love is its all-absorbing theme. ‘A Turk sees his wife for the first time on his wedding day ; carriages are arranged by the fathers. How can the fixht of the male for the female, to an Ocoi¬dental the chief event of his lire, enter into the fiotion ot a nation which knows not that fight ? Yet, somehow, it does ; for the Turk can transcribe, transpose, adapt, arrange, as none other can ; and with thi Tarks, as with the Europeans, the majority of stories are love stories.

As I am writing, a line cf Longfellow rings in my ears, "While we are speaking the word.it is* already the Past.” What I have stated here.will soon beoorae t lie past.The professional storyteller finds it more and more to his interested read the newspapers to his audience, translating the high-class Tarkisb of officials and journalists, which consists to the amount of one half of Arabio and Persian terms, into the pure Turkish of the common people. It will not ba long before the short story of the public reciter is a thing of other years. The printed novel made its appearance in Turkey a quarter of a centary ago, and though as yet it is a negligible quantity, it will no doubt orowd the manuscript novel ont of existence in the near future/ v /

The Tarkp, if they want fiotion at all, will then have to adopt the European moles of oironlation. Will they be happier for their advent? Perhaps there will also baa Kitab- ajda-bir, which isTorkish for “Book Monthly.” Will that cure the Sick Man of his palsy ?
(F. W. von HERBERT, in the "Book Monthly”;)

div.head: EGYPTIANS AND THE RECENT CRISIS.
div.p: ATTITUDE OF THE COPTS.

“A Native of Upper Egypt” writes :— Thb Tabah crisis has taoaht the English in Egypt terrible things, if I may be allowed to use such an exoresdion. Most of them thoughf that the Moslem population would be either neutral oFfriendly towards the British Occupa-tion. This view was not without reason, for the A bglo Egyptians could not help thinking that the Moslems would prefer the present prosperity and freedom to the old misery and misrule.

Why Uiould the whole oivilizad world testify to the taot, goodwill, Imperialistic statesman¬ship, and mighty power of the English nation and the Moslems'of Egypt testify to the reverse and also say that the Sultan was "victorious’’ in the end and in the beginning be was "in the right” and the English were '.‘in the wrong” ?

I know that it is very hard for a European, who as a rule does not know the "ins” and outs of the Moslems, to believe these facts. But I as a Copt confess that it wou’d have been quite impossible for me to imagine that the Moslems and their press could have taken the side of the English or have been neutral.

Now, why did they behave in such detestable manner towards the English who have done so much for Egypt? By far the chief reason is that in their heart of hearts they firmly believe that religion and politics are inseparable, and this strong belief, together with their bigotry, blinds them completely to any diplomatio taot, national right, or states¬manship. Bat can we, Christians, blame a people who are true to their religion and to live up to- the teaching oi Mohamed, whom they passionately love.?

The second reason, thoagh it cannot be com¬pared with the first, is worthy of note. It is the attitude of the Anglo Egyptians towards the natives in general. This snbjeot has been disoussed exhaustively, and especially in the Egyptian Gazette” of 28bh January 1905, and unfortunately with no apparent resalt. The Egyptians are a very sentimental people and it is a pity that the English should ignore this faot. To think that the modern Egyptian can be ruled by' anything except sentiment is a mistake.

Having considered one section of the natives with regard to the Tabah crisis, let ua. con¬sider the other section, viz., the Copts. For although the latter are only about one million yet they are the friendly rivals of the Mos¬lems iu almost every ephere of life, and deserve nearly as mnoh consideration as the Mohamedans. During the orisis, the native Christians, who are vouched to be the purest Egyptians, an I their Press spoke iu a vqry friendly manner towards the English and discountenanced the idea that the present Anglo-Egyptian Government should be chang¬ed and the Tnrkish rale resumed. It is a well known fact that the Copts have always been grateful to the English at heart (for obvious reasons they cannot show their gratitude openly) and when some Coptio churches offer thanksgivings at the anniversary of the British Occupation, there oan ba no doubt as to the frieodly feeling towards the English.
May we not hope that this friendship will be reciprocated by the Anglo Egyptians ?

Young Copts who are working for their degrees and diplomas here in England, never dream of joining tha Government servioe when they return home, while, on the con trary, young Moslems in similar oooapabions never dream of anything else.
This is because every one oi the former is "too old a bird to be caught by chaff” and indeed sometimes even “chaff” is denied him.
Bob the latter become, in a very short space of time, Moudire, Wakeelp, Advisers’ secre¬taries, chief engineers, etc.
There is no need .for me to repeat the disadvantages, stated in my letter to the Gazette” of the 8th January 1906, under which the Copts have to labour..

They never grumble at anything for the simple reason that thej^ have been subject to more or less persecutions under the Mos¬lem rule, for the laat thirteen centuries or so, and are, as it were, used to it. But when it is remembered that we are in the 20th centary and'Egypt is ruled by Christians, one is tempted to think that we Copts are not better off than we wore , in the tenth centary.

It is childish to- say, as many natives do, that the English do not put the Copts op the same footing as the Moslems because they are afrrid of displeasing the latter. I think the one thin$ that will please the Moslems is that the English will resign their supremacy and rale in favour of the Saltan.

Il is a well-known faot in E’ypt that the native communities have become of late years on better and more friendly terms than ever they were before, and therefore it is most probable that disfavouring the Copts will increase the unpopularity of the English with the Moslew population.
The Egyptians do not know of any reason which justifies such an attitude towards one community, and disoonntenance the conti¬nuance oi suoh unwarrantable disfavour.
I need hardly say the moral of this case deserves the attention, of the Anglo-Egyptians, and the sooner an understanding is established between them and the Copts the better it is for Egypt.

That the English are fond of peace and goodwill is best illustrated by the “Entente Cordiale” with France. Suoh an “Entente’' can be easily established hetwen the Anglo-Egyptians and the Copts if the former wish it. And if a few Englsihmen , chosen by Lord Cromer, were to meet the Coptio National Council at Cairo, then the chances are that in two Sittings they Would COme to a happy issue.

div.head: DIGGING TO CONFIRM THE BIBLE.
div.p: THE new discoveries IN EGYPT.
Prof. A. H. sayoe writes, as follows in the V'Daily Mail” :—

The^newest of the- soienoes is the soienoe of excavating. It stands to archieology in much the same reflation that the scientific study of fossils stands to geology, and provides the materials for the arobanlogiat just as the
lost literature of tte classical world, it is again to the soil of Egypt that we must torn.

Papyrus after papyrus has been di covered, sometimes in a tomb, sometimes in the rubbish rnonuds of an ancient city, inscribed with the writings of classical antiquity which scholars believed, to have perished irretrievably. Now it has been the lost speeffi of an Attio orator, now a political treatise of Aristotle, now again the amusing atd life like society sketches of fc Greek poet, or the works of the rival of Pindar.
Professor Petrie’a discovery, that the oar- tonnage ot certain mummy-cases of the Pto- lemaio epoch was oomposed of the con¬tents of provincial waste-paper baskets has
fo8ana”ptovide» the fjeologist I b“n P" "T' y“'B
with the mate,1.1s for tracing the paet bi.toty ; PMt D'8' Or"W1 :“d hlV!,,T of th$ earth. vating on the sites of the old Egyptian

Bat whereas the geologist is chiefly con¬cerned with the history of life on the globe before man came into existence, the materials brought to light by the excavator in the shape of pottery, tools, and weapons, contempora¬neous inscriptions, and the like, enable the archaeologist to reconstruct the history of civilizQdman.
Archaeology, in faot, takes op iho history of the past where geology lays it down, and supplements the history of natare with the history ofhoman intelligence.
Infinite Mischief done by Ignorance.

The scientific exoavator is bound to be an arobicclogist, just as the arob(eulogist ought to be a soientifio excavator. The practical work of excavating ought to be accompanied by a training in scientific methods, by the power of understanding and appreciating indaotive evidence, and by a skilled and observant eye.

It is not enough to have turned over the soil of an anoient tumulus in the haphazard fa«hion-of the olden "sntiqnarigs.” or to have disinterred the monuments of some early oirili- sationSp order to fill with thenr the rooms of a muuenm; "suoh methods of excavation have, unfortunately, been only too prevalent in the pzat, and,have done infinite misohief by destroy¬ing evidenoe which the exoavators had not enough soienoe to oomprehend or reoord.
The Excavator's Happy
Hunting Ground
The archaeologist has constant rekson for regretting that excavating began before the modern science of archeology was born.

Soientifio exoavation had its rise in northern Europe; then followed the excavations of Dr. Schliemann and'others in Greek lands; and fioally the new soienoe was, systematised and perfected in Egypt, where the olimate and sand have preserved the relics ooantless gene¬rations, and the British ocoapation has given faoilities to the excavator which it is difficult to find elsewhere. The methods of excavating thus brought to perfection in Egypt are now being imitated in other parts of the world, more especially in Palestine, where the work of the English and Austrian explorers is at last revealing to av, not only the history of of Israslitish Canaan, but also that which the Israelites oonquered.

Egypt is. however, above all other countries, the oxcavator's happy banting ground. In lah^where rain and frost are practically unknbwo,_the prod acts of man’s art and ih dastry perish only by the hand of man. The monuments of the pioneers of civilisation some sijx or eight thousand years ago lie side by side with the later productions of the twentieth century, one almost as fresh as the other. Last winter, while exoavating at Gehel Silsila, I came across the rude figure of a giraffe ham mered ont by a flint on the snrfaoe of a sandtone rock (and therefore going back to'the Neoli t)fic age), the outlines of nhich had been worn to the oolonr of the rook itself.

Over it—abpnt four thousand years ago— an Eleventh Dynasty inscription had been ont with a metal tool, the oharaoters of which still looked fresh. Foar thousand years bad made hardly any appreciable difference in their appearance. Looking at the two memorials of the vanished oentnries one could thns form some idea of the enormons antiquity to which the primitive drawing must reach back. It is only iu Egypt that we cau folly realise the antiquity of civilised man.
Fragment of a Lost Gospel.

And it is in Egypt,, perhaps rpore than any¬where else, that it is always the unexpected which rewards the labours of the excavator, and lends to his work somewhat of the excite ment of gambling. We searoh for one thing, and find another which ms/ happen to throw a wholly new light apon the past. At Gebel Sikila, for example, I was primarily engaged in digging for tombs ; the,tombs proved1 to be cf secondary importance, but what I actually came across were the remains of a temple of the Eighteenth Dynasty, the very existence of which had been previously unknown.

It is nqt^ however, only the Egypt of the Pharaohs whose history, when scientifically in¬terpreted, has been preserved in the friendly soil. Christian and Mahommedan Egyp| are there as well, and dnrieg the last few years we have learned that if we are to recover the

towns, with the speoial purpose of disinterring the fragment*) of papyrns rolls with which they are filled, and thoasands of sooh frag¬ments, mostly G.eok, and many of them belonging to literary works, are now in Eog- land. Among the fragments discovered on the site of Oxyrhynohns are the famons Logia or Sayings of Christ aronnd which there has been so much learned theological disonssion.

Last winter a vellum leaf was found on the Eame site, containing what may prove to be a fragment of a lost gospel of the latter part of the seoond century. As it identifies the ‘ high priests” with the Pharisees, it cannot be earlier. But, like the older Logia. it is an earfe’fc of what we may hope still to discover.

The tradition of the early planting of Chris¬tianity in the Greek oities of E >ypt has been folly cot finned, and as excavation proceeds there is no reason why other fragments of the primitive Church may not be disinterred, including, it may be, a copy of the Gospel of St Mark itself. One of the latest German finds is the work of a Gnostio heresiarch against^whom St Iremcas wrote, which shows that in spite of modern oritical doubts Irentcas has correotly reported the doctrine and meta¬physical system of his opponents.
Arohceology supports the Bible.

Bat Egyptian excavation has been casting light opon the later books of the Old Testa¬ment as well as upon the books of the New Testament and the iiteratare of the early Church. Two years ago a series of very oom plete and important Aramaic papyri wa« discovered at Assouan, which I am at present engaged in editing.

They are all carefully dated, and belonged to a colony of Jews—the grand children or great grandchildren of the Jews who njigrated into Egypt with Jeremiah—whq zIi^d at Assouan and Elephantine in the time of Xerxes I. and his two snccessors.^Theee Jews were already the bankers and money-lenders of the place, afitLheid a"good deal of property * there. The papyri throw, a lat^e amount of light on Jewish law and ocslom, more espe-1 oially in the matter of marriage; they also explain the origin of the so-called Biblical Chaldee.

It was the official Aramaio of .the western half of the Persian Empire, as spoken and written by tfie Jews'. The names Inrne by the Jewish oommunity, it is interesting to note, are exactly those which we fiod in the p'ost- exilio hooks of tin Old Testament. Other similar documents of Jewish origin may be expeoted to turn np, now that attention has been directed to them. This winter, for in- stanoe, I obtained one whic£ contains the accounts bf a Jevpsh trader, and is about a century and-abalf later than those found at Assouan. > *

But the archeological revelation of Egypt is not as yet half exh lasted. Tke future has discoveries, in store for ns of which we oannot at present even dream. The age of the “sub¬jective” dissection of literary works, and the attempt to rewrite history with the help of philology and literary tzot is now over, at all events so far as the scientific student of the past is concerned.

If we are to discover the history of the past, and to tebt the traditions of it which have come down to ns, it must be by means of arohceology, and of evidence which alone is soientifio. Contemporaneous documents, whether on stone or clay or papyrus, pottery and styles of arohiteotare, tools and weapons and ornaments—these, when brought to light by the science of excavation and scientifically interpreted by the archaeologist, oan alone tell us whether the history that has been handed down to UB is a fiction or an honest record of events.
And thus far archaeological discovery has been on the tide of tradition.
A. H. SAYCE.

div.head: PORT SAID TO LONDON BY BICYCLE.
div.p: ARTILLERY OFFICER'S INTERESTING RIDE

Ho was resting by a country stile, and his bicycle—upon which he tarned now and again an atl>ctiouate, if somewhat sunburnt, glance —lay beside him. I asked him for a light and, sitting down to rest, we fell into casual conver.e. .
' Have yon two oome tat ?” said I. "You look n'ealy travel worn.” .

Fairly/’ fit replied, as he b’ew a clqnd of Egyptian smoke into the sunny air, and lazily regarded the dainty wreaths twisting and turning ere thejr were for ever lost in illimit¬able spacn; "we have oyoled more or less ever . e/hce we left the ship at Port Said.”
V^Well done/’ I said, ' that sounds interest-ing. l\wish you would tell me about it. for you must have had a wonderfully interesting ride.
But what made you think of it ?” .

"I don’t kuow,” he replied. "I hail had a long spell of it in India. I am in the Gunners, yoa know, and ever since I was at the ’shop’ I have been fond of cycling, and the idea struck ms one day that it would be possible, and certainly interesting, to cycle home from Egypt. It was awfully jolly getting to Port Said. Just as we steamed in the band of the Twrb!e straok up the National Anthem, and at first we thought it was in our honour, until we were told it wate to celebrate the Priuce of Wa'es's entry into Cairo at that moment. Well,
1 left the steamer and transhipped to the Russian boat Cornelio, and, set off for Jaffa.
"Tell I said, know.”

ni at the pro^peot pf what even the na tive§ of Tripoli described t % a bridle path ‘200 miles long that I resolved to take steamer to Smyrna, where I discovered A small oolony of relatives with whom I spent six very ploasant days. Ephesus was very interesting, and also the spot dreamt about by the German peasant girl - the origin of a new sect in the it 0. Choroh. -

‘Well, cnce again I was doomed to dis-appointment as regards bicyoling to Con-stantinople. A perfectly organised band of brigandj watched over Smyrna. They, would know I had rich relatives in the town, and the rich relatives themselves dissuaded me from the attempt fiosribly from kindness” he doubtfully murmured—-^'possib.y becaase they smelt a big ranaomr^which they might have boon at-ked to pay had I been cryptnred, and so I went by sea to lstambul, as Con¬stantinople is called in tl^at pirt of the world. At Constantinople I had great trouble with the Customs Honse people. They fussed about the carefully packed hold all until human nature could stand no more - at least, my human nature conldn’t. In such moments one forgets all about one’s Turkish and Arabic, aud goes back to good plain o’d English. Th*y understood at onoe, and one regretted one’s former forbearance.

"But they were to sorry—the bicyole could not be got through. It was Friday, the Mohamedan Sunday, and on that day no self-respecting Tnrk dreams of working. This was the last straw. So, snatching it up, I carried the bioycle a yaelf through gaping and terror stricken r.tfi rials to the office of the Director of Customs. A few words about British subjects and the British Ambassador and a mejbidie (or Turkish dollar) under the table cleared things op.

' Here in Constantinople some of my widely- spread relatives took charge of me. I was wondeofuilyTmpresaed) with St.Sophia, the most wondffrful building I/have ever aeon, but its majZtio beauty is sadly mfcrred by its very sonhcLaurr-oOudiugs. I trained fjrom Constan¬tinople to Belgrade, and there, to myjiy, I again mounted my little friend he’e. But even when riot actually ridirg on the bicycle I found the . machine helped to make the journey wondei fully easy. Y HI seo, there were no worries about servants, /orters; handbags, or advance luggage. I tied a i my lnggage on to the bicyole, aud then tbo" all travelled in one. One foals absolutely si f-contained, and able to go anywhere or sa'i anything; not tied down to gd any roo.e,- or stay in any particular place. As I wa; not .cycling for a wager, or against time, A consulted only my own convenience ami pleasure. Afte/ the first 100 miles in Palestine, whan the biko was really tesled to thn fall, I had no misgivings about its holding out. I know that, bar accidents, which, after all, a care¬ful rider can often avoid, the thing would' carry me through, and it did—splendidly. Even unavoidable accidents, such aa punc¬tures, were usoaliy very we'oome, as I found great relief iB * using ar.other set-of muscles. In the ordinary course of events I never got pft until 1 was fairly* ccmpelled to do so. Getting on and eff over my luggage was quite an acrobatio ft at, and meant mounting by the pedal, aid throwing the right foot well over.

I remember in Palestine a clowd once collect¬ed, and the village hero wanted tomonnt the strange machine. He had been to Beyrout, and seen the thing used, and so thought he knew all abont it. I longed to let him try, and see him hurt himself in front of all his admirers, bxf the chance 6f his doing some damage was too grSat, so I retired gracefully with the mach'ue, puffing oat smiles and Arabic.

"The only objection to the trip from my point of view was being alone. It is not always possible to find a'.companion for so long a journey and not b^ing made of the true ex¬plorer stuff I iretfd to get very tired of my own company. At the same'time, I am boond to own that there were plenty of little occur¬rences to relieve the monotony. For instance,
I remember passing through Strasbourg, and oycling through long lines of soldiers wbo were waitir g for the Emperor^ and who cheered me heartily—whe* her jn irony or in

to m»ke myself nuderstood in tew as. where French and .Garman were auknown, and Arabic and Torkiah worse than useless, greatly amused me. la one town— Mitowitz, a typi¬cal Hungarian town—I wauted bam, but not a soul know what I meant until a happy inspiration dawned upon me, aud I roughly eketched a pig, especially outlining his hams, and pointing dowu my throat.

"A curious’thing happened in Germany one day. *1 was riding from Schlettstadt to Worms when I ran up against a large hay cart which refused to move out lof the narrow road to let me pass. I got past finally andtild the carter what I thought of Irm in scraps of three languages. A mile further on I had apunoture, and the carter and his pals cgxne op and threatened to be trouble ornn. Ttfey returned ray language with interest. However, I think even a German is cased when Tan appears to . ise Iris temper. Anyway, th»y sndden’y If/, mo alone just as j wa3 beginning to finger revolver. In the South of Europe I used to ht’d it d'fiicnlt to get a breakfiut before ma-ri >g a start. F used to carry food for tho mi l. y meal from the house where I had slept, and eat it going along. Then I.would wan r down from my two galbn. leather water Jh-' . to, which I always carried, as you see now, . n tho handlebar, Existence without water i Hand impossible, and this had to be reple .»• bed three or four times a day. They toy it ...jakens one, but by the.time I reached the oi.d of my trip I was as hard as possible—in tact, almost a machine.

"no; perpetaal |if90p bo.rd ehi'p m,k„ one f»t and mere#,, GuT Bioyiliog ttfngiMb many innsclos into play, and »o thatooylPy exercise, toe body that travel underjooh oiroomatancea i« like boing in a good gymnaeinm. And. besides, one cannot get any real idea of what a country is like when one rushes through it in a train. You get to know not only a country, but also its people, its flowers, its cities, its bills and valleys, its whole characteristics, when you bicycle leisurely through-it. In this way I came to know and like the people of Southern Europo—everyone, that is, barring the larkish official. They are very kind, and one is very ready to forgive people a lot wfio are quick-witted and resourceful. One had not ’he trouble in asking the wa> one has in England. They were all so interested, too. Of oonrse, they were mostly rascals, bat, thee, if you. know that, aud .meet them on that footing, you do not suffer. I do^ think I was cheated out of more than a few penoe the whole time, that is from 5 April to 13 May."
fell me about your distaooes and your best runs," I afked, thoroughly interested in his delightful experiences. '

‘H ell, to put it briefly, my journey was as follows Fort Said to Beyrout by ship; Beyrout to Tripoli by bicycle ; Tripoli to Smyrna and Constantinople by sea-; rail to Bslgrade, and then cycled from Belgrade to Vnkovar, where I was stopped by floods, and so on to Trieste by train. From Trieste I bioyoled .to Brescia, touching Venice and Verona :-and trained over the St. Gothard to Gosohenen ; from Gosohenen I bicyoled to Worms, and then took a river steamer to Cologne, from whence I trained to Ostend, taking the boat to Dovfcr, whence I am bicyoling.to Hastings, as you see. The longest run was from Sohlettstadt to Worms—125 miles in one day. My most difficult was my ride in Palestine, where I was only able to ride my bicyle for ten miles oat of thirty-five It was hard going, that German ride, as I did the 125 miles inside of thirteen hours Coming throngh the St. Gothard Tunnel in the tram a box fe’l on the back wheel of my bike, and buckled it up, but by stamping and tightenmg the'spokes judiciously I succeeded in making it revolve without touching the fork and I was amazed to find it carried me all the way down the mouutain pass, and finally into Mulhaosen, the only disadvantage being an undue strain on the spokes. I aged to spend about five minutes at night and fifteen minutes in the morning oiling and cleaning and going over the machine. I was delighted to find that none of the parts worked loose or reqmrod lightening, ». jn 80m0 maohiDM Ihis I attnbntod to cvefnl tbonght on the p»rt;of the mannfaotnrars. I thiok the very lightness of the machine often served it, as there was no dead metal, so to speak, to accu¬mulate energy in breaking itself.”
1 rather wonder yon didn't bioyole from Constantinople to Belgrade," I remarked “I always think that part ofBurope is so interest- >ng-

"So it is,” replied my friend, bat to tell yoa'the truth I did not oare to start on a hundred mile3 run over infamous roads only to get’nto the train to avoid the troubled area of the Macedonian revolt. I enjoy ri8ks while the odds are even, but when things come to two to ore on the brigands the sitnation beoomes absurd. Servia is a very uninteresting country' and their Customs a hotbed of extortion, and eo I aned off, and started bicyoling from the borders of Hungary.

“Of coarse, what interested me more than anything, perhaps, were tha glimpses I got into national, oharaoter. In Syria I always fonnd Ihe people pleasant, and obviously amused and interested with the onwonted spectaole of a youDg mm travelling alone>rith his bioyole, a maohine very few of them h ever seen. In Southern Europe they were, as havejsaid, good-humoured sooundrels who preciated the novelty of such an enterprise. Germany only too often I fonnd them apt to he surly and ill-natured. I remember wr amu¬sing incident which occurred when I Arrived in Schlettstadt. I went into an hotel. The mrnager and some ladies were seated there drinking beer in the dining-room. It was a small plaoe, but I politely asked them if they could give me a bed.

Mein hoste remained seated, and sulkily replied in the -affinaative/-1 left him one minute, while I wont to put my lamp out ; i and on my return, finding he had made no movement, I told him that as he could not be Ojmtiionly polite he might keep his precious room to himself. Then the fun began. He oould not afford to let an E lgli^hman—.especially a globe trotter—go elsewhere. First he pressed me to stay, and thon, finding that I was ada¬mant to his entreaties, he turned savage, and I left him, greep with rage, on the doorstep with his three daughters. In Milan the secretary of the Touring Club was very interested in my tonr and in my dear little Rndge-Whitworth Aero Special, and he helped me a great deal with maps and road books.

The whole j mrney remains like a bsantifol dream in my mind. Its memory'will be with me all my litp. There is nothing so'delightful as wheeling along those sunlit roads, with ail the oloud scenery round and about one, and a new oonntry opening itself op to one every minnte.I cannot advise a better mode of spend¬ing a holiday. And it is snob a wonderful break in the long voyage from India. You oan send all yonr heavy baggage home by sea, and reserve just enough very light material, as I have already described to you,', which oan bs fastened on your machine. Take your money by moans of oirculat notes, anri always have a supply of compressed J^qd softie'ent to last you fourteen days. Well, I must push on to Hastings, and then I and my little bicyole will be at test.”
And, almost as he spoke, ho had vanished fromkmy sight in a cloud of8ussex chalk and dust
(RaymondBlathwxyt, in the ‘MorningLeader’.)
